messages.message:
Finally catching up on this for docs... I see the app runs endpoint (https://docs.instabase.com/api-sdk/api-reference/runs/run-app) allows you to specify `input-dir` :
1. Is this the parameter you'd use to trigger a manual check of an upstream drive integration? Are there any other specifics users should know about how to do that? 
2. With the addition of upstream mailbox connectors, is there a way to trigger a check of upstream mailboxes with this endpoint?
cc: @Anil @tony.shi @Jessica @Chris Cowell

The one relevant for upstream integrations would be the run deployment (https://docs.instabase.com/api-sdk/api-reference/runs/run-deployment) endpoint. And we did just add the ability to do this, good catch!! Instead of specifying an `input_dir`, they can instead pass in `manual_upstream_integration: true` . For upstream drive integrations, that's all they have to do, and it will trigger a check of their specified source folder. If it's an email integration, they also need to specify a `from_timestamp` and `to_timestamp`, which are numbers in milliseconds.

For both drives and mailboxes, how are old objects treated, like files/folders/emails already present when the integration is added? I'm assuming we only pull _new_ objects beginning when you add an integration? Except for mailboxes, where you can presumably back-date using the *Received after* field?

For drives, anything present in the source folder is fair game. Whenever the deployment is run, it will take any and all files from in there.

For mailboxes, there are a couple of different ways it figures this out:
1. The received after date in the filters, like you said
2. When you're running the integration manually, we use that received after date + the from_timestamp and to_timestamp - so you'll get everything between those timestamps, that are received after the specified date in the filter
3. When the mailbox is running on a schedule, we do something a little more complicated. The first run will take everything after the received after date (or from the beginning of time, if not specified). We will then save what the last email we pulled was. Then, for the next run, we'll pull everything after that one, so there's no overlap and we don't process emails twice.

one slight correction on 3) for email integrations

For scheduled runs, we wouldn’t start from the beginning of time. Rather, we will crawl back one interval window and start from there. For example, if the schedule is set to “Daily”, the first run would fetch all emails that were received in the last day. The next run (following day) will pick up where the first run left off… etc

@Jessica can you help update the docs for this
https://instabase.atlassian.net/browse/EPD-3320
Yup can do. We'll put this on our list for when we update these endpoints in the future too
